data.value: Frequency-swept cosine generator.

In the following, 'Hz' should be interpreted as 'cycles per unit'; there is no requirement here that the unit is one second.  The important distinction is that the units of rotation are cycles, not radians. Likewise,
could be a measurement of space instead of time.
Times at which to evaluate the waveform.
Frequency (e.g. Hz) at time t=0.

Kind of frequency sweep.  If not given,
is assumed.  See Notes below for more details.
Phase offset, in degrees. Default is 0.
This parameter is only used when
is 'quadratic'. It determines whether the vertex of the parabola that is the graph of the frequency is at t=0 or t=t1.

The graph of the frequency f(t) is a parabola through (0, f0) and     (t1, f1).  By default, the vertex of the parabola is at (0, f0).     If

To use a more general quadratic function, or an arbitrary     polynomial, use the function

f0 and f1 must be nonzero and have the same sign.
This signal is also known as a geometric or exponential chirp.
hyperbolic, hyp:
f0 and f1 must be nonzero.
The following will be used in the examples:
For the first example, we'll plot the waveform for a linear chirp from 6 Hz to 1 Hz over 10 seconds:
fig-scipy.signal.waveforms.chirp-1.png
For the remaining examples, we'll use higher frequency ranges, and demonstrate the result using
. We'll use a 4 second interval sampled at 7200 Hz.
We'll use this function to plot the spectrogram in each example.
Quadratic chirp from 1500 Hz to 250 Hz (vertex of the parabolic curve of the frequency is at t=0):
fig-scipy.signal.waveforms.chirp-2.png
Quadratic chirp from 1500 Hz to 250 Hz (vertex of the parabolic curve of the frequency is at t=T):
fig-scipy.signal.waveforms.chirp-3.png
Logarithmic chirp from 1500 Hz to 250 Hz:
fig-scipy.signal.waveforms.chirp-4.png
Hyperbolic chirp from 1500 Hz to 250 Hz:
